comment.body:
That's sad. I'm using Arch for 3 years now and was still using the Beginners so I don't forget something.
And I wouldn't have tried it in the first place if there wasn't a beginners guide.

@ulrichard: I like the UI and everything but Rhythmbox doesn't manage my Music well. I use an external HDD for my music and plug it in if I want to play some. I symlinked the folder into my music folder and pointed Rhythmbox to it.
Only a small percent of my music is recognized.
After reading your blogpost enjoy your machine, took long enough.
I'm looking forward to a proper Linux phone but without a unified app platform I can't see a future.
USB type-C would be nice on every other notebooks except applesl. Would be nice to have just one cable for every device.

@Gallium: I quit using Apple when Lion came out. I needed a new computer and I didn't like the way the os was going. I felt instead of giving me more features they they dumped everything down. Tried it on my old hardware, went out bought a cheap ultrabook for less than half the price and put Linux on it. Best decision I could make.
Having a digital grocery list, was one of the main reasons I bought my first smartphone.
@ks: [Signal](https://whispersystems.org) and [Conversations](http://conversations.im) come to mind. P2P solutions are not ready for mobile.
One of the best bumper stickers I've ever seen.
The funniest part is, it's not free people actually pay to get tracked and see advertisements. Microsoft you are a genius.
It's more about being a constitutional state. If you deny your citizens the right to remain silent or use it against them you are no longer a state which honers human rights.
In most European restriction the looser pays for the lawyer. So it would be feasible to go to court.

I tried Ubuntu phone on my Nexus 7 a couple of times and it always felt like early work in progress.
I feel if we want a real open source phone system the best hope is that all phone makers get fed up by google and fork android and develop the base in a real open source fashion.
I can only talk about german law and here it's not possible.
Looks nice. I hope the phone becomes a success and we get a truly open phone os.
